repnme.cdata!:
Cameroon - Education for All-Fast Track
            Initiative Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The objective of the Education for
            All-Fast Track Initiative: Support to the Education Project
            for Cameroon was to reduce class sizes by recruiting and
            retaining more teachers in the public education system, as
            well as deploying them in an equitable manner. From the
            beginning of the project to its end the following results
            have been achieved: more than 90,000 people benefited from
            the project, 412 classrooms were renovated, grade retention
            in primary education decreased from 28 to 15 and better
            governance was built.

TF094959-CAMEROON EFA/FTI SUPPORT TO

repnme.cdata!:
Cameroon - Education for All-Fast Track
            Initiative : Support to the Education Project

abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for the Education for All-Fast
            Track Initiative (EFA-FTI) : Support to the Education
            Project for Cameroon were as follows: outcomes were
            moderately satisfactory; risk to development outcome was
            substantial; Bank performance was moderately satisfactory
            and grantee performance was moderately unsatisfactory. Some
            lessons learned includes: the main lesson here is that the
            client's leadership capacity cannot be underestimated
            in development and implementation of successful projects.
            Integrity, dynamism, bold decision making, and vision
            characterize some of the leadership strengths in the
            project. The systems development approach that was adopted
            was strength of the project. This is an advisable strategy
            in governance and corruption fraught environments. For the
            project, the data from the Ministry of Basic Education
            (MINEDUB), and other related ministries served as the
            baseline data for overall monitoring and evaluation.
            However, timely and accurate data for project implementation
            were not available. The strength of the EFA-FTI project was
            its relative simplicity. It was designed to support a policy
            which the government had already put in place. It helped to
            accelerate and scale up government's efforts, while
            focusing on systems development and institutional
            strengthening. The weaknesses in this area caused
            significant delays in disbursements for the project. The
            mitigating factor was that the disbursements related to
            salary reimbursements for payments already made by the government.

13845342.trustfund:
TF097256-Cameroon EFA-FTI Catalytic Fund
            Grant - Support to the Education Sector

repnme.cdata!:
Cameroon - Education for All-Fast Track
            Initiative : Support to the Education Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The objective of the Education for
            All-Fast Track Initiative: Support to the Education Project
            for Cameroon is to reduce class sizes by recruiting and
            retaining more teachers in the public education system, as
            well as deploying them in an equitable manner. The project
            consists of one component.  It will be fully used to support
            the Government's contract teacher program. It will
            contribute to the payment of the salaries of 37,200 primary
            public school contract teachers recruited during FY07, FY08,
            FY09 and FY10 during: (a) the period from January 2010
            through the date which is four months after the effective
            date, and (b) part of the remainder of the 2010 and 2011
            school year. The indicators for this project will be the
            reduction in pupil-teacher ratios (PTR) and reduction in the
            variation of PTR across regions. PTRs are measured by
            dividing the number of teachers by the number of students
            within regions and for the nation. The variation of PTR is
            calculated by a regressing the size of specific schools
            against the number of teachers in each specific school.
